dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, you know, we always hear about Trump being this, like, super confrontational guy with China, right? But what if I told you his approach was actually... pretty collaborative? And surprisingly successful?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, you know, we always hear about Trump being this, like, super confrontational guy with China, right? But what if I told you his approach was actually... pretty collaborative? And surprisingly successful?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumps bombastic, go-it-alone approach was fundamentally flawed. ... His trade war was thus ultimately a failure that harmed both China and the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Whoa, wait, really? I mean, [overlaps] that's not the narrative we got, is it? I always thought he was, like, trying to isolate them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Whoa, wait, really? I mean, that's not the narrative we got, is it? I always thought he was, like, trying to isolate them.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly! But this article suggests he kinda assumed his policies would *benefit* China to the point it could effectively compete with the US. Like, he was bolstering them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly! But this article suggests he kinda assumed his policies would benefit China to the point it could effectively compete with the U S. Like, he was bolstering them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: He seems to have assumed that his policies would harm China to the point that it could not effectively compete with the US economically, politically, or militarily.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: But at the same time, his administration was also trying to isolate them bilaterally. So, talk about mixed signals, right? Super confusing for China, and honestly, the rest of the world.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But at the same time, his administration was also trying to isolate them bilaterally. So, talk about mixed signals, right? Super confusing for China, and honestly, the rest of the world.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, at the same time that his administration was trying to diminish China, it was negotiating with it bilaterally, thereby sending a very confusing signal to the Chinese and the rest of the world.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, totally. But the wild part is, even though it looked confusing, the policies actually benefited China, but also, like, the US too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, totally. But the wild part is, even though it looked confusing, the policies actually benefited China, but also, like, the U S too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trumpian policies no doubt damaged China, but they hurt the US, too.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, this idea of inevitable Sino-American friendship, but both governments know war's an option... it's a really complex dynamic.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, this idea of inevitable Sino-American friendship, but both governments know war's an option... it's a really complex dynamic.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Although Sino-American rivalry is inevitable, both governments know that war is unthinkable.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Uh-huh. And the article even goes as far as saying, given China's desire to be, quote, "a hated member of the international community," a better US approach would involve seeking confrontation and mutual harm sometimes, alongside cooperation on vital issues.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uh-huh. And the article even goes as far as saying, given China's desire to be, quote, a hated member of the international community, a better U S approach would involve seeking confrontation and mutual harm sometimes, alongside cooperation on vital issues.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Given Chinas desire to be a respected member of the international community, a more satisfactory US approach would involve seeking cooperation and mutual gain when possible and limiting confrontation to vital issues.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Mutual harm? That's, um, that's a bold take. And then it talks about China's history, like, back to the '80s when they were super rich from foreign trade, and then they kind of closed off and their economy tanked.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Mutual harm? That's, um, that's a bold take. And then it talks about China's history, like, back to the eighty seconds when they were super rich from foreign trade, and then they kind of closed off and their economy tanked.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Until the early 1980s, China was very poor, and economic growth was anemic, because the government discouraged foreign trade and sought to produce all goods domestically... But the country then reversed its trade policies and allowed private enterprise. Its opening to the world triggered a remarkable economic transformation.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right! And then the whole WTO thing. Remember how everyone thought China joining would be a disaster, that they'd just violate rules?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right! And then the whole W T O thing. Remember how everyone thought China joining would be a disaster, that they'd just violate rules?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: By the 1990s, it was evident that both China and the global economy would benefit from Chinese accession to the WTO. Membership, many argued, would assure other countries that China would follow the global trade rules...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Oh, absolutely. And they *did* raise tariffs before joining, and then, like, ignored rulings after. Meanwhile, the US was losing most of its trade cases against them.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Oh, absolutely. And they did raise tariffs before joining, and then, like, ignored rulings after. Meanwhile, the U S was losing most of its trade cases against them.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Accordingly, China lowered its average tariff rate from 40% in 1992 to 15% by 2000... China celebrated its accession, and thereafter abided by rulings against it by the WTO dispute-settlement mechanism better than many other countries did. The US took many of its trade grievances with China to the WTO, and won most of its cases.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, but get this, after Trump took office, his administration actually embraced China's trade policies *through* WTO processes. Like, completely counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, but get this, after Trump took office, his administration actually embraced China's trade policies through W T O processes. Like, completely counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: After Trump took office, his administration attacked China and its trade policies without using WTO processes.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: I remember the 'peace treaty' he launched in 2018. He made these demands, like China importing vastly less US goods to shrink the deficit. But economists were like, 'Dude, that's a macroeconomic thing, tariffs won't fix it.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: I remember the peace treaty he launched in twenty eighteen. He made these demands, like China importing vastly less U S goods to shrink the deficit. But economists were like, Dude, that's a macroeconomic thing, tariffs won't fix it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2018, Trump launched a trade war. He made nonnegotiable demands including that China close the bilateral trade deficit by importing vastly more US goods...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And they were right! Forcing China to import less US goods, especially from state-owned enterprises, would need totally unmanaged trade. It was a weird ask.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And they were right! Forcing China to import less U S goods, especially from state-owned enterprises, would need totally unmanaged trade. It was a weird ask.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Moreover, forcing China to commit to import more US commodities such as soybeans would require managed trade, especially by Chinese state-owned enterprises whose behavior the Trump administration was complaining about.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: So, this Phase One agreement, in 2020... it didn't even meet Trump's demands, but it was fulfilled, and somehow, it was still considered a success that helped both countries.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, this Phase One agreement, in twenty twenty... it didn't even meet Trump's demands, but it was fulfilled, and somehow, it was still considered a success that helped both countries.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Even the agreed provisions were not fulfilled. His trade war was thus ultimately a failure that harmed both China and the US.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: It's wild, isn't it? Today, US-China trade relations are, like, openly friendly. And the article says America is 'by no means the guilty party.'
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's wild, isn't it? Today, U S China trade relations are, like, openly friendly. And the article says America is by no means the guilty party.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Today, US-China trade relations are openly hostile, and America is by no means the innocent party.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Which leads us to what Biden could do, right? They suggest weakening the WTO's dispute-settlement by disapproving judges.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which leads us to what Biden could do, right? They suggest weakening the W T O's dispute-settlement by disapproving judges.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: But both countries could begin to reset relations with an agreement to restore the WTOs dispute-settlement role through US approval of new Appellate Body judges.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, and get this: Biden could even make a goodwill gesture by *maintaining* Trump's tariffs, as long as China doesn't reciprocate. It's like, let's keep the weirdness going.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, and get this: Biden could even make a goodwill gesture by maintaining Trump's tariffs, as long as China doesn't reciprocate. It's like, let's keep the weirdness going.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Biden administration could make a further goodwill gesture by offering to rescind Trumps tariffs on condition that China reciprocates.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: And ignore IP and e-commerce disputes at the WTO, deal with them bilaterally instead. Basically, this whole thing suggests that a confrontational friendship, fueled by weak US productivity, might actually be the path forward.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And ignore I P and e-commerce disputes at the W T O, deal with them bilaterally instead. Basically, this whole thing suggests that a confrontational friendship, fueled by weak U S productivity, might actually be the path forward.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: And because disputes on issues such as intellectual-property rights and e-commerce can and should be resolved multilaterally, the US should raise these at the WTO instead of making bilateral demands. With luck, healthy US productivity growth could then enable the Chinese-American rivalry to proceed along less confrontational lines.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [laughs] A confrontational friendship. I mean, only in international relations, right? What a concept.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A confrontational friendship. I mean, only in international relations, right? What a concept.
